Detailed Description

The runner class is used to run test cases and collate result information.

The runner cannot be instantiated directly, rather access to a global instance is granted through its singleton method: runner::global().

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

virtual testdog::runner::~runner (  )  [virtual]

Destructor.

Member Function Documentation

static runner& testdog::runner::global (  )  [static]

Singleton access.

There is no public constructor for this class, and all access is via this singleton method to a single class instance.

Example:

 // Run all tests
 testdog::runner::global().run();
Returns:
Reference to global instance

void testdog::runner::register_test ( test_case &  tc  ) 

Explicitly registers a test case instance with the runner.

Normally there is no need to call this method, as test cases automatically register themselves with the global runner instance when they are instantiated.

However, it is possible to disable the automatic registration of test cases by pre-defining the TDOG_DISABLE_AUTO_REG macro. In this case, the register_test() method must be used to add tests to the runner explicitly. In addition, the TDOG_TEST_REFINST() macro must be used to reference the underlying test case implementation instance, as follows:

 #define TDOG_DISABLE_AUTO_REG
 #include <testdog/unit_test.hpp>

 // Define test
 TDOG_TEST_CASE(some_test)
 {
   ...
 }

 int main(int argc, char **argv)
 {
   // Explicitly register the test
   testdog::runner::global().register_test(TDOG_TEST_REFINST(some_test));
   ...
 }

If the test case belongs within a test suite, you should use the the suite name as a namespaced prefix. For example:

 testdog::runner::global().register_test(TDOG_TEST_REFINST(suite_name::some_test));

With self-registration, tests are run in the order that they are declared. One possible benefit of registering tests explicitly, therefore, is that it provides some control over the run order.

Parameters:
[in] tc Underlying test instance
See also:
TDOG_TEST_REFINST(), registered_count()
void testdog::runner::register_test ( basic_test &  tc  ) 

This is an overloaded member function, provided for convenience. It differs from the above function only in what argument(s) it accepts.

Parameters:
[in] tc Underlying test instance

bool testdog::runner::test_exists ( const std::string &  tname  )  const

Returns whether the test case with the given name exists.

The test name should be fully qualified with the suite name.

For example: 

 bool ex = testdog::runner::global().test_exists("SUITE_NAME::TEST_NAME");

Test names are case sensitive.

If the test case is not part of a suite, just the test name should be used.

std::vector<std::string>& testdog::runner::enum_test_names ( std::vector< std::string > &  rslt_out  )  const

Enumerates the fully qualified names of all test cases registered with the runner.

The results are returned using "rslt_out", which supplies a vector array of std::string. The rslt_out array will first be emptied before being re-populated with test case names.

Test names are provided in the order which they were originally registered, which is also their run order.

Parameters:
[out] rslt_out A vector array of strings used to retrieve results
Returns:
A reference to rslt_out
See also:
enum_suite_names()
std::vector<std::string>& testdog::runner::enum_suite_names ( std::vector< std::string > &  rslt_out  )  const

Enumerates the names of all test suites in the runner.

The results are returned using "rslt_out", which supplies a vector array of std::string. The rslt_out array will first be emptied before being repopulated with test suite names.

An empty string will be used to designate the default suit, i.e. where test cases are declared outside of a test suite.

Parameters:
[out] rslt_out A vector array of strings used to retrieve results
Returns:
A reference to rslt_out
See also:
enum_test_names()
bool testdog::runner::test_enabled ( const std::string &  tname  )  const

Returns whether a test case with the given name is enabled.

Tests which have been disabled will not be executed by the runner.

Use the fully qualified test name. For example:

 bool en = testdog::runner::global().test_enabled("SUITE_NAME::TEST_NAME");

Test names are case sensitive.

If the test case is not part of a suite, just the test name should be used without any namespace.

The default enabled state for tests is true. The result will be false if a test of the given name does not exist.

Note. The enabled state of test cases and their suites are independent, and both must be enabled for a test to run.

Parameters:
[in] tname Test case name
Returns:
Boolean result value
See also:
set_test_enabled(), suit_enabled(), test_exists()
void testdog::runner::set_test_enabled ( const std::string &  tname,
bool  e 
)

Allows an individual test case with the given name to be disabled (or re-enabled).

Tests which have been disabled will not be executed by the runner.

Use the fully qualified test name. For example:

 testdog::runner::global().set_test_enabled("SUITE_NAME::TEST_NAME", false);

Test names are case sensitive.

If the test case is not part of a suite, just the test name should be used without any namespace.

The default enabled state for tests is true. This call does nothing if a test of the given name does not exist.

Note. The enabled state of test cases and their suites are independent, and both must be enabled for a test to run.

Parameters:
[in] tname Test case name
[in] e Enabled flag
See also:

bool testdog::runner::suite_enabled ( const std::string &  sname  )  const

Returns whether the test suite with the given name is enabled.

Tests belonging to a disabled suite will not be executed by the runner.

When calling this method, use the fully qualified test name. For example:

 bool en = testdog::runner::global().suite_enabled("SUITE_NAME");

The default enabled state for suites is true. Suite names are case sensitive. The result will be false if a suite of the given name does not exist.

Note. The enabled state of test cases and their suites are independent, and both must be enabled for a test to run.

Parameters:
[in] sname Suite name
Returns:

void testdog::runner::set_suite_enabled ( const std::string &  sname,
bool  e 
)

Allows the test suite with the given name to be disabled (or re-enabled).

Tests belonging to a disabled suite will not be executed by the runner.

When calling this method, use the fully qualified test name. For example:

 bool en = testdog::runner::global().suite_enabled("SUITE_NAME");

The default enabled state for suites is true. Suite names are case sensitive. This call does nothing if a suite of the given name does not exist. The default suite state can be set by using an empty string ("") for its name.

Note. The enabled state of test cases and their suites are independent, and both must be enabled for a test to run.

Parameters:

set_all_tests_enabled(), set_suite_enabled()
int testdog::runner::run ( run_scope_t  scope = RUN_ALL,
const std::string &  name = "" 
)

Run all tests, or just those specified.

The "scope" parameter defines the scope of the test run, and may be one of the following values:

  • RUN_NONE - Run none (no tests were run).
  • RUN_ALL - Run all tests.
  • RUN_SUITE - Run only the specified test suite.
  • RUN_TEST - Run only the specified test case.

The name parameter supplies the suite name if the scope is RUN_SUITE, or the fully qualified test name if RUN_TEST. It is ignored for the RUN_ALL scope.

The run() method does nothing if RUN_NONE is specified--this is really a result value for use with the run_scope() method.

Both scope and name have default values so that calling run() without any parameters will execute all tests. For example, to run all tests simply call:

 return testdog::runner::global().run();

To run an individual test, call:

 testdog::runner::global().run(RUN_TEST, "SUITE_NAME::TEST_NAME");

To run a single suite, use RUN_SUITE and supply the suite name. Use an empty string to run only the tests in the default suite, i.e. those tests declared outside of any TDOG_TEST_SUITE() macro.

Test and suite names are case sensitive.

The return value gives the number of test cases which failed, or had errors. The value will be 0 if all test cases ran successfully without asserting failures or test errors. If, however, no tests were run, the return value will be -1, rather than 0. This distinguishes a successful test run from one that doesn't actually test anything. This may occur if all test cases are disabled or if no tests have been registered with the runner.

Returns:
Number of test failures, or -1 if no tests performed
Parameters:
[in] scope Scope of tests to run
[in] name Name of suite or individual test case
See also:
test_result(), stat_result(), run_scope()
run_scope_t testdog::runner::run_scope (  )  const

Returns the "scope" used in the last call to the run() method.

If run() was never called, the return value is RUN_NONE.

Returns:
Last run scope value
See also:
run()
int testdog::runner::global_time_limit (  )  const

Returns the global time limit for test cases in seconds.

The global test contraint is the maximum amount of time that individual test cases can take to complete. If any test case takes longer than this value, it will be deemed to have failed. A value of 0, the default, disables the global time constaint.

Time constraints may also be applied to test cases on an individual basis, and where a test case has its a local time limit defined, it will be used in preference to the global one.

Returns:
Time limit applied to all test cases
See also:
set_global_time_limit()
void testdog::runner::set_global_time_limit ( int  gc_sec  ) 

Sets the global time limit for test cases in seconds.

The global test contraint is the maximum amount of time that individual test cases can take to complete. If any test case takes longer than this value, it will be deemed to have failed. A value of 0, the default, disables the global time constaint.

Time constraints may also be applied to test cases on an individual basis, and where a test case has its a local time limit defined, it will be used in preference to the global one.

Parameters:
[in] gc_sec Time limit in seconds
See also:
global_time_limit()
report_style_t testdog::runner::report_style (  )  const

Returns the report style written to STDOUT during the test run.

This setting controls the style of this report, which can be one of:

  • RS_NONE - None (no report is generated).
  • RS_TEXT_STD - Human readable test report.
  • RS_TEXT_VERBOSE - Human readable test report (verbose).
  • RS_XML - XML test report (verbose).
  • RS_HTML_STD - HTML test report.
  • RS_HTML_VERBOSE - HTML test report (verbose).
  • RS_HTML_SUMMARY - HTML test report (summary only).

A report is generated to STDOUT when one or more test cases are run. The default value is RS_TEXT_STD.

Test reports are subdivided according to their "log level", and are considered to be verbose or standard.

Standard reports contain only summary information pertaining to test cases which pass, but further details are provided for those tests which fail. Whereas verbose reports contain the same detailed trace information irrespective of whether the test case passed or not.

Returns:
Stdout reporting style
See also:
set_report_style(), generate_report(), run()
void testdog::runner::set_report_style ( report_style_t  rs  ) 

Set the report style written to STDOUT during the test run.

This setting controls the style of this report, which can be one of:

  • RS_NONE - None (no report is generated).
  • RS_TEXT_STD - Human readable test report.
  • RS_TEXT_VERBOSE - Human readable test report (verbose).
  • RS_XML - XML test report (verbose).
  • RS_HTML_STD - HTML test report.
  • RS_HTML_VERBOSE - HTML test report (verbose).
  • RS_HTML_SUMMARY - HTML test report (summary only).

A report is generated to STDOUT when one or more tests are run. The default value is RS_TEXT_STD.

Example:

 // Use verbose report
 testdog::runner::global().set_report_style(testdog::RS_TEXT_VERBOSE);

Test reports are subdivided according to their "log level", and are considered to be verbose or standard.

Standard reports contain only summary information pertaining to test cases which pass, but further details are provided for those tests which fail. Whereas verbose reports contain the same detailed trace information irrespective of whether the test case passed or not.

Parameters:
[in] rs Report style
See also:
report_style(), generate_report(), run()
std::ostream& testdog::runner::generate_report ( std::ostream &  ro,
report_style_t  rs 
) const

Generates a test report pertaining to the last test run and writes it to the supplied output stream.

The report is generated according to the style rs, and is useful where test reports in multiple formats are required. Note that the report generated with this method would be in addition to that written to STDOUT as the the test runs.

Here's an example of where a text style report is written to the STDOUT as the tests are executed, and a further XML report is written to file after the test run.

 #include <testdog/unit_test.hpp>
 ...

 int main(int argc, char **argv)
 {
   // Set default STDOUT report
   testdog::set_report_style(testdog::RS_TEXT_VERBOSE);

   // Run all tests
   int rslt = testdog::runner::global().run();

   // Generate XML report file
   std::ofstream file_out;
   file_out.open("test_report.xml");
   testdog::runner::global().generate_report(file_out, testdog::RS_XML);
   file_out.close();

   return rslt;
 }

Unlike reports normally written to STDOUT during the test run, reports generated with a call to generate_report() are not progressive. I.e. the report will be realized only after the test run has fully completed.

The generate_report() method does nothing if passed the report style value RS_NONE.

Parameters:
[in,out] ro Output stream
[in] rs Report style
Returns:
Reference to output stream
See also:
set_report_style()
std::string testdog::runner::report_charset (  )  const

Returns the test report character set encoding.

This is a short string specifying a valid character set encoding for use in generating XML and HTML test reports. The value supplied is used simply to populate the "charset" field of XML and HTML documents. Valid examples include, "utf-8" and "iso-8859-1".

The default value is an empty string which leaves the field unspecified.

Returns:
Report character set encoding
See also:
set_report_charset(), html_report_stylesheet(), report_style()
void testdog::runner::set_report_charset ( const std::string &  cs  ) 

Sets the test report character set encoding.

This is a short string specifying a valid character set encoding for use in generating XML and HTML test reports. The value supplied is used simply to populate the "charset" field of XML and HTML documents. Valid examples include, "utf-8" and "iso-8859-1".

The default value is an empty string which leaves the field unspecified.

Parameters:
[in] cs Report character set encoding

int testdog::runner::text_report_break_width (  )  const

Returns the number of '-' characters used to create a 'breaker line' in the text reporting style.

A 'breaker line' is a sequence of '-' characters used to create a visual separator in text report outputs. This setting applies only to the RS_TEXT_STD and RS_TEXT_VERBOSE report styles.

A value of 0 will disable the appearence of breaker lines in the output.

Returns:
Number of characters
See also:
set_text_report_break_width(), report_style()
void testdog::runner::set_text_report_break_width ( int  bw  ) 

Sets the number of '-' characters used to create a 'breaker line' in the text reporting style.

A 'breaker line' is a sequence of '-' characters used to create a visual separator in text report outputs. This setting applies only to the RS_TEXT_STD and RS_TEXT_VERBOSE report style.

A value of 0 will disable the appearence of breaker lines in the output.

Parameters:
[in] bw Break width (num of chars)
See also:
text_report_break_width(), set_report_style()
std::string testdog::runner::html_report_stylesheet (  )  const

Gets the stylesheet name for HTML test reports.

The field is used to populate the stylesheet field when generating HTML test reports. It is not used for other reports.

The default value is an empty string which means that HTML reports do not use a stylesheet.

Returns:
Stylesheet name
See also:
set_html_report_stylesheet(), report_charset(), report_style()
void testdog::runner::set_html_report_stylesheet ( const std::string &  ss  ) 

Sets the external stylesheet filename for HTML test reports.

The field is used to populate the stylesheet field when generating HTML test reports. It is not used for other reports.

Example:

 // Supply the path of a local stylesheet
 testdog::runner::global().set_stylesheet("./styles.css");

This can be used to override the document's styles.

The default value is an empty string which means that HTML reports do not use an external stylesheet.

Parameters:
[in] ss Stylesheet filename
See also:
html_report_stylesheet(), set_report_charset(), set_report_style()
bool testdog::runner::html_report_author_col (  )  const

Returns whether the HTML reports have an "author" column in the result tables.

In multi-author environments, it is possible to associate author names with test cases. This setting controls whether a separate column is used for author names in in HTML reports tables.

This setting applies to the RS_HTML_STD and RS_HTML_VERBOSE and RS_HTML_SUMMARY report styles only. The default value is true.

Returns:
Author flag
See also:
set_html_report_author_col(), text_report_break_width(), report_style()
void testdog::runner::set_html_report_author_col ( bool  a  ) 

Sets whether the HTML reports have an "author" column in the result tables.

In multi-author environments, it is possible to associate author names with test cases. This setting controls whether a separate column is used for author names in in HTML reports tables.

This setting applies to the RS_HTML_STD and RS_HTML_VERBOSE and RS_HTML_SUMMARY report styles only. The default value is true.

Parameters:
[in] a Author flag
See also:
html_report_author_col(), set_text_report_break_width(), set_report_style()
int testdog::runner::stat_result ( result_stat_t  st  )  const

Returns a statistical result for the last test run.

The result will pertain to the following input values:

  • ST_RAN - Number of tests executed in the test run.
  • ST_SKIPPED - Number of tests skipped (i.e. were disabled).
  • ST_PASSED - Number of tests that passed.
  • ST_FAILED - Number of tests that failed.
  • ST_ERRORS - Number of tests which implementation errors.
  • ST_PASS_RATE - Percentage of tests that passed.

The return value will be zero if no test run was performed prior to calling this method, or -1 if the input value is invalid.

Parameters:
[in] st Required statistic
Returns:
Statistical count
See also:
test_result(), registered_count()
test_result_t testdog::runner::test_result ( const std::string &  tname  )  const

Returns the state of a given test case.

Given a test name, this method returns one of the following values:

  • TR_NOT_RUN - Test was not run.
  • TR_PASSED - All test conditions passed OK.
  • TR_FAILED - One or more test conditions failed.
  • TR_TEST_ERROR - The test failed because of a possible implementation error.

If the test case was declared within a test suite, the suite name should prefix the test name with "::" as the separator. If the test case is not part of a suite, just the test name should be used.

Example: 

 test_result_t rslt = testdog::runner::global().test_result("SUITE_NAME::TEST_NAME");

Test names are case sensitive.

Parameters:
[in] tname Test case name
Returns:
Test result state
See also:
stat_result()
std::time_t testdog::runner::start_time (  )  const

Returns the date/time when the last test run started.

The result is in the form of std::time_t and accurate only to the second.

If no tests have been run, or the clear_results() method was called, the return value is zero.

Returns:
Test run start time
See also:
end_time(), test_duration()
std::time_t testdog::runner::end_time (  )  const

Returns the date/time when the last test run completed.

The result is in the form of std::time_t and accurate only to the second.

If no tests have been run, or the clear_results() method was called, the return value is zero.

Returns:
Test run end time
See also:
start_time(), duration()
int testdog::runner::duration (  )  const

Returns the total duration of the last test run in seconds.

If no tests have been run, or the clear_results() method was called, the return value is zero.

Returns:
Duration of the test run
See also:
start_time(), end_time()
